title: 109_s2500
content: The "Healing the Invisible Wounds Act of 2006" requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to wait six months after submitting a report to Congress before making any modifications to how Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is handled for disability compensation. Additionally, the Act mandates counseling for National Guard and Reserve members returning from deployment in combat theaters. The "Healing the Invisible Wounds Act of 2006" mandates counseling services for National Guard and Reserves members returning from deployment in combat theaters to assist in their readjustment to civilian life in the United States. The "Healing the Invisible Wounds Act of 2006" mandates counseling services for National Guard and Reserves members on active duty in combat theaters, including group and private counseling sessions, presentations on counseling-related matters, and other appropriate counseling services. The "Healing the Invisible Wounds Act of 2006" mandates counseling services for National Guard and Reserves members on active duty in combat theaters, provided through vet centers within 14 days of returning home, with retention on active duty until counseling is completed. The Secretary ensures that vet centers provide follow-up counseling services to veterans upon request. A report on the provision of counseling services must be submitted to Congress within one year. The report on counseling services for veterans must include the cost, efficacy, satisfaction, follow-up visits, and services provided to family members. The report on counseling services for veterans must include recommendations to enhance services provided, defined appropriate committees of Congress, and authorizes appropriations for fiscal year 2007. Funding of $180,000,000 is authorized for vet centers in fiscal year 2007 for readjustment counseling and mental health services.
